title: How to get better at combinatorics - Quora

response.answer_text: I went through a process to improve my mathematics scores while I was in college in preparation for the GMAT. The result was that I increased my GMAT Math score by about 20% in 2 months. If you apply the same method, there is no way you wont get better. I promise you it will work. It works with everything. Here are the basic principals: Have a system to recognize the type of problem you’re dealing withKnow where you’re weakPractice where you’re weakHere is the Amazon.com link to all the combinatorics practice books for the GMAT. The reason I use this link is because there are probably some good practice problem books. You’re going to need lots of practice problems. To work this system, you’ll need a few books of practice problems and a good teaching book that will give you a system for identifying the type of problems you’ll need to solve. You might check out Khan Academy for a good tutorial on the different types of problems you’ll face. They have some good teaching examples. Next, take a practice test using some of those GMAT resources you’ll pull together. The reason GMAT materials are so useful is because they give you a range of different problem types. You can track how well you did on each problem type and then, once you’ve mastered a certain type of problem, just stop studying it for awhile and focus on your weaknesses. Eventually there won’t be much left that you’re weak at. At that point, review what you’ve done. Its important you know how good you really are at each problem type. This is the data you need to be able to focus your efforts. Focus is key. The other part of the equation is hard work. If you practice regularly every day, you will get better quickly. Obviously, the more you practice each day, the faster the results. So, that’s not the most ground breaking system ever created, but it works like a charm. Good luck.

You can look for some of the real applications out there. As an example consider a team having three roles as Project Manager, System Administrator and Embedded Engineer. You have five people and all are equally qualified (can fill any role). In this case you have C5,3=5!3!2!=10C5,3=5!3!2!=10 possible choices for your team. In general case this is given as Cn,k=n!k!(n−k)!Cn,k=n!k!(n−k)!.
There are many different ways that can be used individually or together. (Smile) Combinations | Brilliant Math & Science Wiki might be a good place to start.
